<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q37')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">In the context of Modigliani and Miller Proposition II (no taxes), which statement best describes the effect of financial leverage on a firm’s equity beta?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q37" value="A"> A. Financial leverage has no effect on the equity beta because total firm risk is constant.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q37" value="B"> B. Financial leverage increases the equity beta because shareholders bear a greater share of the firm’s total risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q37" value="C"> C. Financial leverage decreases the equity beta because debt is less risky than equity.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q37" value="D"> D. Financial leverage only affects the beta of debt, not equity.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q37" value="E"> E. Financial leverage reduces the systematic risk of equity by diversifying investors’ exposure.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q37" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B.  
Under MM Proposition II (no taxes), increasing leverage magnifies the risk borne by equity holders because debt holders have a fixed claim on cash flows.  
The relationship $\beta_E = \beta_U(1 + \frac{D}{E})$ shows that as $D/E$ rises, $\beta_E$ increases proportionally — meaning equity becomes more sensitive to market fluctuations.
</div>
